./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Introduction to IntelliJ IDEA
IntelliJ IDEA is a Java IDE by JetBrains for developing computer software. It contains a base workspace and an extensible plugin system for customizing the environment. It has powerful static code analysis and ergonomic design, so that it can help programmers by providing smart code completion and recommendation. It is avaible as a free community edition as well as a paid commercial edition. For  educational use, the ultimate (commercial) edition is also free.

chapter1/.title: Download and Installation
chapter1/.body:
Download and Installation
There are two versions of IDEA, including ultimate version and community version.

Price
Free for students

The table indicates that the ultimate version has some advanced functions compared to the community version, while the core function of Java are supported in both versions.
We recommand that for students who plan to choose computer science major should choose ultimate version. For other students, using community version is good enough.

chapter1/section1.html.title: Download
chapter1/section1.html.body:
Download
Download Address
https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/download/

(Optional) Student License for Ultimate Version

Come to https://www.jetbrains.com/student/ 

Click "APPLY NOW".





Use your university email to register an account.
When launching IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate Version, sign in with your account.

chapter1/section2.html.title: Install
chapter1/section2.html.body:
Install
Windows
Open the .exe file and click "next" for several times.
macOS
Open the .dmg file and drag the IntelliJ IDEA.app into the Application folder.
Linux
Extract the archive and place it to somewhere.

chapter2/.title: Configuration
chapter2/.body:
Configuration
When you first open IntelliJ IDEA, there will be a wizzard to guide you finish some configuration. Just click "next" is OK.
IntelliJ IDEA is quite user-friendly. We only need to configure these presets:

JDK: So that IDEA can find out the Java path.
Editor: Customize the font and the color.

chapter2/section1.html.title: Setup JDK
chapter2/section1.html.body:
Setup JDK
Click "Configure - Project Defaults - Project Structure".

In the "Project" tab, click "New... - JDK".

Choose the path of the JDK.

Click OK.

chapter2/section2.html.title: Editor customization
chapter2/section2.html.body:
Editor customization
Click "Configure - Preferences".

Select "Editor - Font" from the left. Then choose your favorite font face, size, etc. You can preview the appearance from below.

Click "OK".

chapter3/.title: Your First Try
chapter3/.body:
Your First Try
Now IntelliJ IDEA is ready to develop a Java project! 
We will try to write a simple program and run it.

chapter3/section1.html.title: Create a project
chapter3/section1.html.body:
Create a project
Click "Create New Project".

Choose the first one "Java" from the left, and then click "Next".

Do nothing and click "Next".

Name the project. Click "Finish".

chapter3/section2.html.title: Get used to the workspace
chapter3/section2.html.body:
Get used to the workspace
Project Structure
A typical workspace is like this. Click "1. Project" on the upper left to show the project structure.

Create a package
Select the src folder. Right click and choose "New - Package".


Create a class
Select the package which was just created. Right click and choose "New - Java Class".


Now we have a source file to write the code.

chapter3/section3.html.title: A "Hello world" program

chapter4/.title: Further Attempts
chapter4/.body:
Further Attempts
Another program
Refer to 3.2. Create a new class and write your code.
Next lab
Also like 3.2, create a new package and do your stuff.

chapter5/.title: Submit your assignment
chapter5/.body:
Submit your assignment
Before you submit your assignment, please check your code carefully,  and upload your source file. If your submission is invalid, the score would be cut or even become zero.

chapter5/section1.html.title: Check your code
chapter5/section1.html.body:
Check your code
Please refer to the following checklist to inspect your code:

 No package in the first line.


 No Chinese characters.


 Proper indent. ("Code - Reformat Code" may help you.) 


 Comments when necessary.


 No plagiarism. If you refer to any code online or copy somewhere, you must specify the source (URL, book name, etc.) in the comments.


 No plagiarism. Any plagiarism would be punished seriously!

chapter5/section2.html.title: Find the source code file
chapter5/section2.html.body:
Find the source code file
In IntelleJ IDEA, select your class in the project view.

Right click and find "Reveal in Finder" (for macOS) or "Show in Explorer" (for Windows).

Now the source file is shown in the system explorer.

The files with extension .java are expected to submit. If you submit the wrong file, your score would be zero.
